DOC.HEAD: TLC Beatrice Withdraws Planned Stock Offering
DOC.TEXT: TLC Beatrice International Inc., a food company controlled by investor Reginald F. Lewis, said Tuesday it had scrapped plans to sell a 35 percent stake to the public. The company cited unfavorable stock market conditions for abandoning the plan, which was intended to raise as much as $194 million. Lewis said the offer might have been poorly timed. ``The time of the year and the market conditions right now were both factors,'' he told The New York Times. ``Also, my sense is that there is now not much awareness in the institutional investor community about what is going on in Europe, or our company and how it fit into the picture in Europe.'' The underwriters of the proposed offering, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, also advised TLC Beatrice to withdraw the offer, the company said. The offering would have made TLC Beatrice the first black-controlled company on the New York Stock Exchange. It also would have left Lewis with 58 percent of the shares. He now has 55 percent. Lewis created the company by acquiring the international operations of the former Beatrice Cos. for $985 million in 1987.
